 BRAZIL RIO GRANDE DO SUL STATE REFORM PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT 1. COUNTRY AND STATE BACKGROUND Country Context 1.1 Brazil's public sector is highly decentralized. Its government is comprised of the Federal Government, 26 state governments, a federal district, and approximately 4,300 local governments or municipalities. Approximately half of budgetary public expenditures are made by sub-national governments. Democratizafion and constitutional revisions in the 1 980s increased the degree of resources under sub-national control, and the degree of local political autonomy in their allocation. Federal transfers to states and municipalities -- as well as state transfers to municipalities -- have also increased. 1.2 Through the last decades, intergovernmental relations have suffered considerable strain. This has been exacerbated by recent resource constraints at both the national and state level, as well as the unclear jurisdictions set forth in the Constitution. Despite their findamental importance to macroeconomic policy formulation and implementation, state finances have historically operated semi-independently of the Federal Govermnent, driven by their own tax bases, formula-driven transfers and borrowing. While states have enjoyed federal bailouts or emergency loans when financial troubles arose, the relationship between these two branches of government has not been smooth. In spite of the lack of clarity in the division of responsibilities, many services such as elementary and secondary education, health care, water, electricity and roads are increasingly being provided by sub- national governments. 1.3 The performance of state and local governments is a source of concern for both micro- and macroeconomic reasons. From a microeconomic perspective, it is believed that the efficiency of large volume of resources allocated to them could be improved; i.e., staff productivity could be increased, and the economic soundness of investments and the design of programs could be improved. This concern was exacerbated by the 1988 Constitution, which augmented the resources available to state and local government by increasing the scale of federal revenue sharing and reassigning taxes to them. From a macroeconomic perspective, the indebtedness of the Brazilian states has reached crisis proportions, posing a serious threat to macroeconomic stability.
 2 Recent Country Economic Policies and Developments 1.4 The most prominent feature of Brazil's recent economic history has been chronic and rising inflation. Monthly inflation peaks of 80 percent and 50 percent were reached in 1990 and 1994, respectively. Large fiscal and quasi-fiscal deficits and an over-extended public sector were major factors underlying this phenomenon. Inflation at these levels slowed growth and investment, distorted the pattern of economic activities and exacerbated the maldistribution of income. Successive stabilization plans were introduced in the 1980s--most of them with price and wage freeze components--but these were successful in containing prices only for very limited periods of time. 1.5 In mid-1994, when Minister of Finance in the prior Itamar Franco administration, now-President Cardoso introduced the Real stabilization plan. This plan included an initial fiscal and wage adjustment, an exchange rate anchor (modified later in 1995, and made less rigid) and tight monetary policy. The plan has had remarkable success. Annual Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation fell from 929 percent in 1994 to 22 percent in 1995 and to about 10 percent in 1996. The balance of payments also remains strong. Gross international reserves have continued to accumulate, reaching US$60 billion by November 1996, or 11 months of imports of goods and nonfactor services. This has occurred despite a weakening of the current account deficit to around 3.0 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP). These positive outcomes for inflation and the balance of payments appear set to continue in the medium term. 1.6 Concomitant with the Real stabilization plan, the Cardoso government introduced a wide range of structural reforms. These include a new concessions law, the abolition of state monopolies in petroleum and telecommunications1, and the abolition of the distinction between Brazilian and foreign companies. In order to accommodate these changes, however, the Constitution needed to be amended. The Cardoso government is also continuing the privatization program initiated in 1991, and trade liberalization within the Mercosul common market. There are further constitutional amendments being considered for reforms of the social security system, administrative rules and taxation. These reforms are critical to bringing about an enduring fiscal adjustment, without which a low inflation regime cannot be sustained. 1.7 Since Brazil is a highly decentralized federation, complementary reforms are needed at the state level. In 1996, state and local governments' operational deficits totaled 2.7 percent of GDP, or about half the consolidated public sector operational deficit. The average tax/GDP ratio in Brazil is already high, so adjustments are best made largely through a reduction in expenditure and, more broadly, through a reduction in the direct role of the state in non-essential areas. Privatization of state-owned banks, sources of quasi-fiscal losses in the past, is especially important. Annex A provides a further discussion of macroeconomic policies and prospects. The breaking of the monopolies does not imply privatization. However, it implies that the state does not have to authorize only publicly-owned companies to operate in the relevant areas.
 3 The Urgency of State Reform, State Debt Crisis and Links to the Macroeconomy 1.8 The urgency of state reform has increased with the Real stabilization plan, which had a major and somewhat unexpected impact on state finances, and, consequently, on the consolidated finances of the government. A tightening of monetary policy as part of the plan led to an increase in average annual real overnight interest rates from 19.5 percent in 1993 to 21.8 percent in 1994 and 25.5 percent in 1995. Much state debt was at fixed interest rates; only state bonds had variable interest rates. As a result, about half a dozen states with significant bonds outstanding became unable to service them at such high interest rates. The indebtedness of the Brazilian states now poses a threat to macroeconomic stability. The states' debt was about US$86.5 billion in May 1996, and they were in default on roughly half of it. With the states in default, the stock of debt continues to grow in accordance with domestic interest rates. Three quarters of this debt is in the hands of the Federal Government and its agents--the Central Bank, Caixa Econ6mica Federal, and the Banco do Brazil. Most of it is owed by the economically most important states in the country. Rio Grande do Sul (RGS) owed Rs. $8.2 billion in June 1996 (Table 2.1), or about 10 percent of the total state debt. 1.9 State-level financial problems were also exacerbated by the 1994 elections and transition to new governments. The outgoing administrations spent liberally and ran up arrears to contractors and suppliers. The new administrations tried to refinance these debts through short-term loans, payable in one year, but were unable to pay them off in the face of continually rising interest rates. Another past mechanism of internal financial control had been the ability of the state governments to reduce real salaries and payments via inflation; this mechanism was no longer available in 1995. Moreover, since inflation rates fell faster than expected at the time of the nominal wage increase in May 1995, the state governments ended up paying more in real terms than projected. By 1996, many states were undergoing fiscal crises. Even when they deferred paying much of their debt and began cutting capital outlays drastically, they still had insufficient funds to pay wages. 1.10 The Federal Government faces a difficult choice. Forcing the defaulting states into bankruptcy could have a crippling effect on the national economy and the financial system. On the other hand, allowing the state debt to keep growing would have equally adverse consequences. The various entities of the Federal Government, the creditors of the states, have in turn financed the debt through domestic borrowing. If the states do not pay their debt, the Federal Government would have to dramatically reduce its own spending, raise taxes, or resort to inflationary financing. 1.11 To address these debt issues, the states are currently discussing debt workout programs with the Federal Government. RGS has already agreed on a debt workout. The terms of the agreement are discussed in paragraph 2.9. 1.12 Furthermore, the vicious cycle of higher interest payments and larger deficits leading to yet higher public borrowing requirements and higher interest rates needs to be broken through a comprehensive program of state structural and fiscal reform.
 4 State Structural and Fiscal Reforms and Links to the Bank Assistance Strategy to Brazil 1.13 Important to the success of the Real Plan are reforms by the states, such as those being pursued by RGS. The major Brazilian states, including RGS, are not poor. They have diverse, robust economies and a tax instrument -- the ICMS -- capable of extracting revenue. But they could be managed better. Budgets are exhausted in paying the salaries of a large civil service, on subsidies, and on politically-motivated capital works. It would appear that the majority of states could service much of their debt if they made a more rational use of the resources at their command. Major reforms are needed if this potential is to be realized. Given the predominant role of the states in Brazil's public sector, major privatization of public services and improvements in state management for those services that remain a state prerogative would have demonstrable effects on the efficiency and responsiveness of the public sector as a whole.  5 1.15 The more immediate concern is a macroeconomic one. Table 1.1 gives the consolidated public sector deficit in Brazil during the 1991-96 period, broken down by level of government. Given the high level of inflation prevalent prior to 1995, the primary and operational measures of the deficit are more relevant for purposes of comparison than the nominal deficit (the PSBR). A prominent feature in the data is the sharp deterioration in the fiscal stance of the state and local governments in 1995 and 1996. The primary surplus of 0.86 percent of GDP in 1994 changed to a growing deficit in 1995 and 1996. The corresponding shift in the operational deficit was even more significant, from about 0.5 percent of GDP to 2.7 percent. More than half of the consolidated deficit in 1996 was due to the state and local governments. 1.16 The principal reason behind the deterioration in the primary balance at all levels of government in 1995 was an increase in wages. Generous wage increases were conceded by the outgoing governments at both federal and state levels towards the end of 1994, some of it representing a recovery in real levels. These wage increases were reinforced by fresh increases in the number civil servants in early 1995. At the federal level, for instance, the wage bill grew by 30 percent in real terms in 1995. At the time, the expectation was that much of the nominal increase would be eroded by inflation as has usually been the case in Brazil. However, inflation was much less than expected in 1995 and the real gains persisted. Non-wage current expenditures also rose in 1995, partly reflecting a spillover from contracts agreed to at the end of 1994, an election year. 1.17 At the same time, the operational deficit worsened even more because of the high interest rates that prevailed in 1995. The real average annual overnight rate in 1995 was 26 percent relative to 22 percent in 1994. The Government adopted a policy of tight control over base money in order to contain inflation. Together with a relaxed fiscal stance, this implied growing internal public debt. Internal debt as a percentage of GDP rose from 20.3 percent at end-1994 to 29.9 percent at end-October 1996. 1.18 Continuing high fiscal deficits financed by debt are incompatible with stabilization in the long run, even though Brazil's overall net debt to GDP ratio of 34.2 percent is relatively low by international standards. Accordingly, adjustment is planned at both the federal and state levels. 1.19 Federal civil servants received no wage increase in 1996. A number of states have signed loan agreements with Federal financial institutions promising to adhere to this guideline. Interest rates declined temporarily during mid-1996. The overnight rate declined to below 10 percent in real terms during May-July 1996 and averaged 16.4 percent for 1996. Nevertheless, the consolidated operational deficit remained at 4.3 percent of GDP during 1995 and 1996. At the level of the state and local governnents, the primary deficit worsened from 0.18 percent of GDP in 1995 to 1.0 percent of GDP in 1996. 1.20 The overall primary balance deteriorated from the 0.4 percent of GDP surplus achieved in 1995 to a deficit of 0.6 percent of GDP. The operational deficit remained constant at 4.8 percent of GDP. Bank projections indicate that this level of deficit can be financed internally without danger to economic stability, even though it will lead to some rise in the debt to GDP ratio.
 6 1.21 During 1994-1996, state and local governments as a whole had an increasing operational deficit. In the case of the larger states, Rio de Janeiro, RGS, Minas Gerais and Sao Paulo, the operational deficit was driven by the high interest payments on their debt in the form of bonds. In November 1996, total outstanding bonds (net of state treasury holdings) amounted to Rs.$49.0 billion. Of these, 37.5 percent were liabilities of Sao Paulo, 17.6 percent of Minas Gerais, 13.1 percent of RGS and 11.9 percent of Rio de Janeiro. This profile provides the justification for the initial concentration of Bank lending for state reform to the large south and south-eastern states of Brazil. 1.22 The World Bank strategy envisages assistance in three, and possibly up to five states. This approach confronts the macroeconomic problem by developing reform programs in a critical mass of the larger states that help bring down the consolidated public sector deficit to a level consistent with sustainable price stability and reasonable interest rates. These reform programs should help contain the fiscal deficit during the 1997 -1999 period. RGS Economic Development 1.23 RGS' economic development is above Brazil's average. Its per capita income was US$3.280 in 1995, ranking fifth in Brazil and exceeding Brazil's average by 19.6 percent. It accounts for 7.5 percent of Brazil's GDP, 12.2 percent of exports, and 6.2 percent of the country's population. RGS' industrial value added amounted to 32 percent of its GDP in 1993 (compared with Brazil's average of 39 percent), with strongest development in manufacturing of capital and durable consumer goods. Nevertheless, recent economic growth has been disappointing. Like Brazil's, the state's annual per capita income growth averaged about 1 percent per year during the 1980s and early 1990s. GDP per capita growth was 1.5 percent in 1994, -1.5 percent in 1995, and is expected to reach only about 1.5 percent in 1996. This recent performance has been below the average for Brazil. RGS Public Sector Background 1.24 Weak public administration has led to a waste of resources that resulted in financial distress for the public sector and poor delivery of public sector services. The most dramatic evidence of weak public administration has been excessive employment and wages in the state that resulted in labor expenses of 82 percent of disposable revenues (i.e., net of transfers to the municipalities) in 1995 -- with 37 percent of the wage bill spent on retiree benefits --, thereby undermining the state's capacity to undertake investment. Other important symptoms of weak public administration include poor tax collection, expanding indebtedness to finance uncontained expenditures, inadequate funding of pension and survivorship benefits, no allocation of responsibilities for the delivery of public education and health, poor road maintenance, and low productivity in the delivery of ports services. 1.25 The financial performance of public enterprises has not been good. Furthermore, state ownership of these enterprises has constrained private sector investment and led to a deterioration of the quantity and quality of services delivered in those sectors. The state has virtually monopolized delivery of power, telephone and water services. The state also
 7 has ownership interests in financial sector enterprises, including two commercial banks, an insurance company, and a warehouse. The state also retains a significant role in the operation of ports services. In most or all of these enterprises the lack of profit- maximizing objectives has led to excessive employment, financial distress, and poorly provided services.
 2. RGS STATE REFORM PROGRAM 2.1 RGS is strategically positioned to take advantage of trade creation under the Mercosul common market. This condition will challenge the State's economy to become more efficient so as to be able to compete under more open trade relations. As discussed above, RGS' economic development has been insufficient to improve average economic welfare or reduce poverty. Expanded growth will require an improvement in competitiveness. RGS' Government is presently in a position to undertake important reforms in pursuit of improved growth and competitiveness. Under the leadership of a strong reform-minded Governor, the Government has demonstrated unusual ability to obtain parliamentary approval of far-reaching changes, despite a heterogeneous representation in parliament and federal constitutional restrictions. The present Governor was elected following a second round of elections and the Government's majority in parliament remains an alliance of about five parties' where consensus building is not easy. Federal constitutional restrictions, including mandated stability of the civil service and excessive pension benefits, have also constrained the scope of reforms. Nonetheless, the state's track record of approved reforms has been good (only two major defeats and over one hundred approvals), and the present combination of a reform minded Governor and a majority coalition provide an exceptional window of opportunity to undertake many of the changes that the state requires to improve its economic performance. 2.2 RGS' economic strategy focuses on addressing two problems that undermine the state's economic development: a deterioration of infrastructure and a deterioration of the public sector. To address these problems, the Government seeks to encourage private sector investment and improve the performance of the public sector. RGS' State Reform Program, covering public finance and debt, administrative reform, and privatization/concessions, has been designed to strengthen the state financially and foster investment in strategic sectors. The Government has described its program in the Reform Program Letter (Annex A of MOP). The remaining sections of this chapter discuss this program. This would be offset, however, by the state's program of new borrowing. As a result, the total stock of debt would continue to grow in real terms until the year 2000. It would subsequently decline, reaching a sustainable level (as indicated by a debt/revenue ratio of 1: 1) in the year 2007. 2.11 Personnel. As with several other states, personnel costs in RGS' public sector -- including payments to active and retired staff in direct administration, foundations, and autarchies--account for a major fraction (83 percent in 1995) of net current revenues. Costs have increased (from about 60 percent of revenues in 1993) due to prior expansions in staffing, the rising burden of retirees and survivors, and increased real wages in 1995. The Government's ability to control personnel costs is constrained by the Federal Constitution. Under the Constitution, statutorially confirmed staff cannot be dismissed (except for cause) and their salaries cannot be reduced in nominal terms. Generous retirement benefits are also constitutionally guaranteed. Staff are permitted to retire after only 35 years of contributions (five years less for women, and an additional five years less for teachers of either sex), and are guaranteed a retirement benefit equal to their exit salary. 2.12 As discussed in the civil service reform section (paragraphs 2.24-2.31), the state undertook a voluntary-separation program (PDV) in May of 1996 and has implemented a freeze on nominal salaries. The state is making use of attrition to reduce the number of active staff still further, and inflation may reduce the level of real salaries and retirement benefits in real terms. Under the federal Lei Camata, the Government will need to reduce labor costs from 82 percent of its net income (receita liquida) in 1995 to 74 percent, 67 percent, and 60 percent respectively over the period 1996-98. In the absence of a constitutional amendment repealing the civil servants' employment stability, these benchmarks are unlikely to be achieved. In the immediate term, the state regards the personnel issue as a fiscal one--spending on personnel absorbs resources that might otherwise be spent on debt liquidation or investment.  17 Pension and Survivor Benefits 2.27 Background. A fundamental culprit of high personnel costs is retiree and survivor benefits. The federal constitution mandates generous retirement and survivorship benefits. Partial retirement benefits begin with 25 years and 30 years of service for women and men, respectively. Full retirement benefits begin with 30 years and 35 years of service respectively for women and men. The full benefit is equivalent to 100 percent of the employee's last salary, with a pro-rata benefit for early retirement. Eligible survivors include female spouses, sons up to 18 years of age and daughters up to 21 years of age (single daughters of employees that began employment prior to 1974 are also eligible regardless of age). Survivor benefits (administered by the Instituto de Previdencia) amount to 45 percent of retirement benefits plus 5 percent per survivor. 2.28 Retirement benefits are paid out of the state budget, and accounted for 37 percent of payments to labor in 1995. If deductions and payments to dependent survivors are considered, this proportion rises to 42 percent. Policies to improve pension financing include recently approved pension legislation that established a 2 percent contribution from the payroll to finance retirement benefits. Survivor and health benefits are paid out of a nine percent payroll contribution by active and inactive staff (5.4 percent for survivor benefits and 3.6 percent for health insurance) and a 3.6 percent payroll contribution by the state. The government is considering an increase in the contribution for survivor benefits from the present 9 percent (applicable to all staff and retirees) to 10.8 percent in order to cover male spouse survivors and to increase survivors' contributions for the medical assistance program from 2 percent to 7.1 percent. Furthermore, costs of the Instituto de Previdencia have been reduced from 17 percent to 12 percent of receipts through administrative reform, and are expected to decline further to 10 percent of receipts through a reduction of 700 staff coupled with increased data processing equipment. 2.29 Issues. The key issue for the Government remains how to increase financing of retiree and survivorship benefits costs. The growth in the number of retirees is about 3 percent per year. Given the constraints imposed by the federal Constitution (which would not be significantly altered by the version of the social security reform now under consideration by the Senate), the state has little latitude to reduce its retirement and survivorship benefit costs. Because retirement benefits are indexed to salaries of active staff, the proposed partial freeze on nominal salaries will, nevertheless, reduce average retirement benefits by about 5 percent per year in real terms. 2.30 Pension Financing Program. By law, the Government will need to submit draft legislation on the establishment of a pension fund for civil servants. During preparation, Bank missions offered considerable assistance to the Government with regard to its options regarding pension reform (see Annex F). Unfortunately, the high level of federally mandated benefits preempts the creation of an actuarially financed fund. The actuarially required contribution rate -- from employees or government -- is simply too high to be feasible. The Government will most likely submit draft legislation to increase the payroll deduction to help finance retirement obligations. The new fund, however, is unlikely to receive the required high contribution rates that would cover mandated benefits. The new fund will therefore ultimately be only partially funded.

Water and Sewerage 2.64 The State of RGS expects to partially privatize its water and sanitation sector (hereafter, the water sector) as part of the State Reform Program. Partial water sector privatization will take place through concession contracts to and full service management
 28 contracts with private operators. With the Water Sector Reform Program the government addresses the sector's urgent need to establish appropriate institutional foundations, including an efficient, credible and autonomous regulatory framework. Privatization and other complementary measures will address the fundamental cause of poor sector performance: the lack of separation between operational and regulatory roles within the sector and the politicization of its management. 2.65 Background and Issues. The water sector faces the typical problems of a poorly run public sector. The sector is dominated by a state enterprise, the Companhia Riograndense de Saneamento (CORSAN) -- a utility with poor financial performance with much room for improving the quality of service. CORSAN provides water services in 304 (71 percent) of the 427 state municipalities, serving an area that houses 70 percent of the state's total population (9.8 million people). CORSAN's coverage of water (93 percent) is average by international and domestic standards, but its coverage of sewerage (9 percent) is low by both international and domestic standards, i.e., there are about 0.4 million people without water service and about 5 million without sewerage service in CORSAN's territory. 2.66 CORSAN operates in a difficult market. The state capital, Porto Alegre, and five of the state's largest cities (Sao Leopoldo, Caxias do Sul, Pelotas, and Bage and Santana do Livramento), refused to sign concession contracts with CORSAN when the company was created in 1965. On the other hand, in a state with many small towns, more than 55 of the systems CORSAN operates today serve towns of less than 1,000 people, 230 systems serve towns of more than 1,000 and less than 25,000 people, and only 10 of its systems serve cities of more than 100,000 people. The implementation of cross-subsidies from large (and supposedly rich) systems to small (and supposedly poor) systems, PLANASA's main operational arrangement, has then been more difficult to apply in RGS than in any other state. CORSAN's market however is not the cause of CORSAN's poor performance. CORSAN's water losses are high (about 43 percent) and its metering level (62 percent) is low. Its labor productivity is significantly below best practice (4.3 employees for every 1000 water connections) and its personnel costs are high (Rs. $23,638 per employee per year). The result is that 56 percent of CORSAN's billing is devoted to covering the personnel costs originating from 5,513 permanent staff. 2.67 Despite state transfers of US$205 million during 1985-95, CORSAN's long-term debt was US$438 million at December 31, 1995 (of which US$250 million resulted from the 1994 refinancing of its debt with Caixa Econ6mica Federal). CORSAN's financial prospects are particularly worrisome because of the large size of its long-term debt (equivalent to about 1.7 times the company's 1995 operational revenue) and very high operating costs (about 20 percent higher than its operational revenue). This situation, which exists despite CORSAN's very high rates -- US$0.80/m3, makes it unrealistic to imagine a scenario where the company, as it is institutionally organized today, becomes financially self-sufficient. 2.68 RGS Water Sector Reform Program. The general objectives of the water sector reform program are to:
 29 * reduce or eliminate the reliance on state treasury funds for the water and sanitation sector; * clarify the legal and regulatory framework of the sector, with appropriate inclusion in a cross sectoral regulatory agency (paragraph 2.132) and in appropriate environmental protection provisions (paragraph 2.74); * increase operating efficiency; and * improve the quality of service and expand service coverage. Through achievement of these objectives, the government expects to reduce CORSAN's size to a competitive level by making its assets financially profitable, increasing investment in the collection and treatment of sewage, reducing water tariffs, and allowing yardstick regulation and competition in the state's water industry market. 2.69 Reform Strategy. The Government plans to meet the reform objectives by restructuring the sector, increasing the degree of private participation, creating a competitive environment for the service providers, and redefining the sector's social policy. To explore alternative strategic options, the state will hire through the Water Sector Modernization Project (Loan 3442-BR), a consulting firm to provide recommendations regarding these options, clear guidelines regarding the appropriate steps to take, and a timetable for implementation. The main strategic options to be studied include restructuring the sector, increasing and implementing private sector participation, and revising the sector's legal and regulatory framework. These options are examined below. 2.70 Sector Restructuring. The selection and implementation of an appropriate industry structure is the first condition towards the diversification of water sector ownership. The most interesting among the different available options seem to be: * award one or more of the integrated systems serving municipalities which are part of the Porto Alegre Metropolitan Region (PAMR) to private concessionaires; * have CORSAN award one or more full-service management contracts (FSMC) to private firms for the operation of the medium- and small-size systems serving a number of small-size municipalities, villages and towns located close to each other. FSMCs will be awarded through a public bidding to serve estimated populations of about 150,000-200,000 people. Besides the responsibility for operating and maintaining the systems, the contractor would also be responsible for implementing an investment program to be defined in the bidding document. Each municipality and district covered by an FSMC will bid for a new concession at the end of its concession to CORSAN or at end of the five year contract, whichever comes first. The private firm operating the systems under FSMCs will be allowed to participate in any or all of the public biddings that will take place to select the new concessionaires; and * award to cooperatives an undetermined number of very small-size systems, mainly serving rural areas. The state will promote the formation of these cooperatives in
 30 those cases where, without any risk of lowering the current levels of service quality, a less expensive service would result from disengaging these systems from CORSAN. An alternative option to be explored by the consultants is the possibility of selling either 51 percent of CORSAN's shares to a group of private investors or selling majority control of a number of CORSAN's proposed geographic regions. The state government's target is that by mid-1998, a number of water systems serving municipalities with a total urban population of at least 800,000 people will be under private sector operation (either concessions contracts, full service management contracts or private firms). 2.71 Concession Design. The concessions' design and the basis on which concessions will be awarded are issues to be resolved. The government's intention regarding the awarding mechanism is to fix all other parameters (service quality, investment, and so on), and award both the concessions and the FSMCs on the basis of the lowest offered tariff. By selecting this awarding mechanism, the government expects to guarantee maximum transparency to the process; end the economically inefficient practice of unified tariffs; and, more importantly, challenge the present assumption that large subsidies are needed by any small-size system, the main argument of those who resist the idea of reducing the size of Brazil's state water companies. 2.72 The levels, of service coverage written into the concessions and the FSMCs will be geographically related dated targets for water supply, sewerage, percentage of sewage treatment, and percentage of metering. In deciding about targets for coverage, the government will study and balance the existing trade-offs between targets and tariffs, taking into account the population's payment capacity. 2.73 The levels of service quality written into the concessions and the FSMCs will comprise parameters to be regulated such as drinking water quality, quality of sewage discharges, continuity of service, accuracy and frequency of billing, and response to customer complaints. 2.74 Environmental impact andfuture environmental sector regulations. Changing the environmental regulations creates instability in the implementation of private concession contracts. Contract clauses particularly vulnerable to change are the speed at which the concessionaire has to comply with targets for sewerage coverage and treatment. Therefore, it is of critical importance that a consistent set of environmental targets and obligations for the utilities be developed early in the concession process through coordination between the water and environment sectors, so that the implications of alternative options for investment requirements, tariffs, and environmental quality can be fully assessed by future concessionaires (see details in paragraphs 3.13-3.15). 2.75 River basin management agencies will eventually take over the responsibility for achieving targets set at the federal or state level. These agencies will have the power to levy charges and fines in order to meet the targets at least cost. They will include the main users of every river basin, and hence concessionaires will be key players both in terms of water abstraction and wastewater discharges. Their discretion will be offset by the fact that the decision-making powers will be with the users of the basins. If the agencies do not operate as planned, then penalty mechanisms are envisaged in which state or federal entities will act to impose charges on all parties in a uniform fashion.
 31 2.76 Treatment of CORSAN's Debt and ExistingAssets. The state government has already decided against a debt write-off by the state. Remaining questions are whether the concessionaires will pay the debt at the time of the bids or assume it, and how the debt will be allocated among concessionaires and, in particular, among municipalities willing to separate from CORSAN. To allocate the debt based on the revenue earning performance of each concession and municipality is an attractive option that will be considered by the government. How the payment of CORSAN's debt is resolved could also provide a solution for how to deal with CORSAN's existing assets. The solutions to both questions could be linked by making CORSAN's existing debt equivalent to CORSAN's existing assets, (i.e. assuming that the government's equity is zero). 2.77 CORSAN's Current Employees. Dealing with CORSAN's current employees is another issue to be resolved by the government. Two available options are to allow the private operator to finance the redundancies or to discharge the redundant labor force prior to signing the concessions. The two options are not mutually exclusive. A package could include, for instance, some public financing as well as further cuts by the concessionaire. One question is whether the public funds would be used at an early stage to finance the reductions, or whether the funds would be provided to the winning concessionaire. 2.78 Water Pricing. Water pricing is the final area in which important government decisions need to be taken. Although CORSAN has attempted to simplify its tariff structure in the recent past, it still lacks simplicity and transparency because of the introduction of a complex exponential equation for calculating applicable rates. The two main elements upon which a decision will need to be made are the form of tariff regulation (that is, when and how often will the average level of tariffs be adjusted) and whether and how the tariff structure should be amended. Key questions that will arise include the leeway concessionaires will have to adjust the tariff structure within the overall cap on the average level resulting from the bidding process; the role the government's social policy will play when adjusting the tariff structure; the timing for implementing new tariff structures (before or after the concessions are awarded); the role "revenue neutrality" will play when the implementation take place after the concession has been awarded; the role seasonal or peak load pricing will play; and the extent to which water bills will result from metering actual consumption. 2.79 Social Policy. RGS water sector policy needs to address key questions related to the objectives, sources, and instruments of the state's social policy. Is the objective of the policy to facilitate access to the services to the very poor families or to pay for the consumption of the poorest families? What sources of funds will make possible the implementation of the policy? Which instruments will be used to implement the policy? These questions need to be addressed in a clear and transparent manner to determine the contractual obligations to be included in the bidding documents and the negotiation of the conditions by which existing systems would be returned to municipalities willing to become independent. 2.80 Program Cost. In addition to the study of alternative strategic options for restructuring the sector, increasing and implementing private sector participation, and
 32 revising the sector's legal and regulatory framework, implementation of the water sector reform program will require the services of legal, financial, and administrative advisers to assist and advise the state and municipal governments in the implementation of the agreed privatization strategy, including negotiations and finalization of contracts after the award is made; international advertising of the privatization process; public hearings; environmental audits of facilities to be concessioned or sold; and the establishment of a water division at the regulatory agency(ies). The cost of these activities has been estimated at about US$2 million. 2.81 Evaluation of the Program. The water reform is the riskiest component of the RGS State Reform Program. Because of the water sector's municipal nature, the state government commitment to privatize it is not as clear as in other sectors. Chances of a wider and stronger political opposition to the reform are greater in the water sector because each municipal council and mayor can refuse, at any moment, to support or join the state government in its privatization effort. 2.82 However, the risk is worth taking because the benefits will be large if a significant number of municipalities decide to award concessions of water services or agree to FSMCs. Concessions or FSMCs to private operators will improve efficiency in two ways. First, water will be produced and distributed at lower cost through cutting water losses, increasing metering levels, and raising labor productivity. Second, concessions will allow private investment to improve infrastructure of production and distribution. The scope for such efficiency gains is large, given present operational costs and service shortfalls (paragraphs 2.66-2.68). 2.83 Furthermore, the program can work as the most effective catalyst for motivating other state and municipal utilities to undertake the painful but required sectoral reforms. Privatization has been frequently opposed on the grounds of its close association with rich and large capital cities. Private operators would only be interested in "cherry picking", especially in developing countries. The proposed strategy would show that privatization could also work in medium- and small-size localities. Many of the efficiency gains associated with serving large cities come from economies of density. But this argument does not necessarily mean that it is optimal to serve an agglomeration of small localities as if they were a large city. 2.84 Finally, the chances of success are greater than ever due to CORSAN's high level of current tariffs; the relatively good information that is available on the condition of its assets; a widespread lack of satisfaction with CORSAN's service provision, in particular in larger municipalities; and the good chance that exists of having a clear regulatory framework agreed and in place in the near term. Ports 2.85 Background. The State of RGS has played an important role in the development of the region's transportation and commerce, due primarily to its almost 2,000 km of navigable waterways. The state is linked by the tributaries of the Rio Uruguay, the south- east basin, two main inland ports of Pelotas and Porto Alegre, and the ocean port of Rio
 33 Grande (PRG). Due to its proximity to Argentina and Uruguay, Rio Grande has been a key player in regional trade. Regional trade has become even more important in recent years; trade with the US alone in 1994 reached US$12.2 billion, which registered an increase of 20.4 percent from the previous year. 2.86 Since 1934, the State of RGS has operated its waterways under concessions granted by the Federal Government. Through the Ministry of Transportation, the Federal Government oversaw all modes of transportation, including the ports. In 1951, the Departamento Estadual de Rios, Portos e Canais (DEPRC) was established in RGS to administer and operate the state's ports. DEPRC's main clients have been the state's agricultural, agroindustry, and industrial producers. 2.87 Currently, five of PRG's 14 ports are rented to private operators, with the others operated directly by the state. PRG handles 11.4 million tons of cargo per year and has depths of up to 40 feet. The private terminals in PRG have increased their share of merchandise from 38 percent in 1993 to 50 percent in 1995. The Port of Porto Alegre has 21 terminals (19 of which are privately operated), with depths of up to 17 feet. 2.88 Issues. RGS' publicly operated ports, like many others in Brazil, have suffered due to years of less than optimal capital investment. This, in conjunction with excessive centralization, restrictive labor practices, and a number of disincentives for private sector participation has left the sector with obsolete equipment as well as poor investments, administration and operation. Brazilian ports have become obstacles in the further expansion of trade. The influx in imports brought about by lower inflation rates and relaxed trade regulation under the Plano Real has created further strain on an already overtaxed system, resulting in long shipping delays in Brazilian ports. The ports operated by the State of RGS, like the Port of Santos in the State of Sao Paulo, have become increasingly less competitive within the Mercosul trading bloc. This drop has taken place over the last three years; over 60 percent of the region's container trade is currently being routed through the ports of Buenos Aires and Montevideo. 2.89 A major factor in this shift has been labor costs. Labor costs alone per item shipped are one and a half times more than those of the neighboring ports. Payments for both active and inactive workers currently absorb 80 percent of DEPRC's operating budget due to high wages and low physical productivity in the state's ports. Labor assignments are often poorly planned and inefficient, resulting in long waiting and service times. In some cases, full gangs of 12 workers are required despite the fact that a crew of three could effectively work with cranes and unload the cargo. Labor unions have attempted to maintain their monopoly over labor in the ports, and have been successful in disrupting trade with strikes in other Brazilian ports. High labor costs are partly passed on to users via port fees, and also result in dwindling maintenance and investment. Excessive costs have also led to soaring DEPRC indebtedness, which reached Rs. $131 million in 1995. 2.90 The Federal Government's objectives for modernizing ports include: (a) granting of private concessions to operate public port facilities; (b) the privatization of port services; and (c) restructuring the various port administration companies to make them more responsive to shippers. Two important federal laws were passed to modernize the
 34 country's ports system. Federal Law 8630, passed on February 25, 1993, established two separate and independent entities to administer ports: an independent labor organization (the Orgao de Gestdo de Mao de Obra) and the ports authority council (Conselho de Autoridade Portuaria). These two entities were created to address some of the most salient administrative and operational obstacles by ending union control over labor provision within the ports. The law set a rate of early retirement/voluntary dismissal compensation for union workers, as well as a bonus for those workers wishing to continue working in the ports as non-union labor. The law also created a new, smaller entity, comprised of representatives of the federal, state, and municipal governments, non-union ports workers, and port users to administer the ports. 2.91 Federal Law 8987, passed in February 1995, officially established the concessions for ports, ports services, and ports installations (e.g., silos, docks, warehouses, etc.). Moreover, the law established that all concessions would be granted only after a prescribed process of public hearings (audienciaspziblicas), and bidding. The law also allowed for the leasing of undeveloped portions of coast line under the government's jurisdiction to private exploration. On July 21, 1995, a presidential decree established the date of April 26, 1996 as the final date for restructuring the country's principal ports, which includes the Port of Rio Grande. The project is necessary to help accelerate this restructuring. 2.92 RGS Ports Reform Program. The current administration is reforming the ports system as a means of improving overall efficiency in the sector, modernizing and improving its infrastructure, participating more fully in regional trade, and improving financial performance. The components of RGS ports reform follow below. 2.93 Reorganization of ports administration: Following changes in Federal Law, the state has reorganized the ports by law, and has divided up the administration of the ports to optimize the comparative advantages of the Port of Rio Grande in regional trade. Under Law 10722, DEPRC was charged with the administration of the interior ports, canals, and waterways. As with the federal law, all services would be concessioned out. The other entity, the Superintendencia do Porto de Rio Grande (SUPRG), was created under Law 10723 to administer PRG. In addition, this law specifically charged SUPRG with proposing a plan for zoning and further development of the ports area. SUPRG was also to create a plan to revitalize the inefficient or unused portions of the existing ports. The state has also sought to reduce its labor costs by implementing a port corporation, comprised of representatives from local business and maritime operations as well as federal, state, and municipal governments, to oversee and administer the ports. 2.94 Reductions in labor costs: The state has already abolished 1,666 vacant positions within the docks. In addition, as part of the state port reorganization, DEPRC's remaining staff will be reduced by about 70 percent (or 1,153 staff positions) over three years through the state-sponsored plan of voluntary departure and early retirement. The number of staff employed by the ports authorities (DEPRC or SUPRG) declined from 4,222 in December 1994 to 3,324 in June 1996. Most of this decline was achieved through the state's early retirement and mutually agreed separation program implemented during April-May 1996. By further implementing the Federal Ports Modernization Law, the state
 35 also intends to entice remaining temporary workers (avulsos) to retire with a bonus of Rs. $23,300, as determined by the 1993 law. Most importantly, the state is seeking to reduce its astronomical labor costs by replacing the current union of temporary workers (avulsos) with independent port operators. 2.95 Granting of private concessions. Under state law, SUPRG will only administer concessions in the Port of Rio Grande, but will leave the operation of the ports to private entities. DEPRC will similarly administer all other (interior) state ports. Six public commercial docks in Rio Grande and one in the Port of Porto Alegre are being concessioned through rental of the facilities over the next three years. Each concession will be for 25 years and would be renewable. Included in the concessions will be a petroleum pier (already awarded); a refrigeration pier; a container terminal and its installations in Rio Grande (already awarded); a container terminal in Porto Alegre (already awarded); the wheat-soy terminal, its silos and installations; a liquid bulk terminal with a storage capacity of 34,000 m3 primarily used for vegetable oils; and a cargo warehouse. The Government awarded the first three concessions (petrol and container piers) earlier this year. The last concessions (liquid bulk and wheat-soy) are scheduled for August 1998. (see Annex J). 2.96 Evaluation of Ports Sector Reforms. Reform in the ports sector is likely to be sustained and will improve the state's fiscal position and to contribute to economic efficiency. Strong government ownership and commitment to the reforms originates in the poor experience that the state has had with public ports, including high labor costs and inadequate investments. Strong ownership and commitment are evident from the state's successful passage of enabling legislation and from early scheduled implementation of concession arrangement for some facilities. The enabling legislation passed last year addresses the key ports issues by creating a small agency that will only administer the concessions and establish institutional arrangements to reduce labor costs and award concessions. Early award of the petroleum pier (albeit concessioned to PETROBRAS, the only bidder) and the container piers of Rio Grande and Porto Alegre indicates the state's commitment to delegate ports to private operators. Sustainability is ensured by low likelihood of reversing long term concession contracts that result in lower costs and better service. 2.97 Concessions to corporate operators will improve efficiency indicators of ports services. With concessions being implemented in several sectors, regulation of infrastructure services has become a primary concern for the RGS government. The trend emerging in RGS thus far has been to delegate regulatory responsibilities to specialized independent authorities. Nevertheless, international experience shows that most state-level governments establish multi-sectoral regulatory entities rather than a proliferation of sector-specific agencies, and the same trend is emerging for national-level regulators in many countries. The main advantages of establishing regulatory entities on a cross- sectoral basis include: Saving resources and hence lowering the costs of regulation-senior professionals (e.g., economists, lawyers, and financial specialists) and administrative resources can be shared between sectors.
 44 * Facilitating learning between industries-many of the most difficult regulatory issues in the public services sector are substantially identical across sectors. A multi-sectoral entity facilitates the sharing of experience among sectors, which can be particularly important when experience in regulation is limited. * Consistent approaches to similar issues in different sectors can also help to reinforce the legitimacy of the entity's decisions. * Reducing the risk of political interference in an independent entity-the broader constituency and higher profile of a multi-sectoral entity increases the stakes of governments engaging in improper interference. * Reducing the risk of the regulator being "captured" by the regulated industry-the broader industry coverage and constituency dilutes the otherwise very close relationship between the regulator and a particular industry, thus making it less vulnerable to "capture." 2.130 In the context of the State of RGS there is also an additional advantage of choosing a multi-sectoral agency rather than a series of sector-specific agencies. In many sectors the scope of the state's regulatory competence is not fully defined, and will likely evolve over time. In these circumstances, it would be imprudent to establish dedicated sector-specific entities for sectors such as electricity or water and sanitation until that competence is better defined. Creating a multi-sectoral agency that focuses initially on, for instance, transport and telecommunications allows skills and experience in regulatory matters to be developed and then extended to sectors such as water and sanitation and electricity once the state's responsibilities in those sectors are clarified. 2.131 The Government's Program. With these considerations in mind, the Government decided to move in the direction of pooling its regulatory expertise into a single cross- sectoral regulatory agency with regulatory responsibility for tasks within the state's competence. In the water and sewerage sector, the precise scope of state responsibility remains to be fully defined, and significant state competence will probably require a delegation of authority from municipalities. Only in the transport sector are there a number of activities that seem clearly to fall within state competence, and regulatory policy can be determined without awaiting decisions by the Federal Government. Under the new law, the scope of the cross-sectoral agency is constrained by responsibilities already assigned to other federal agencies. Implementation Strategy: The Government's strategy for implementing the new regulatory entity is being shaped by three main considerations: (i) the importance of establishing the entity as soon as possible to regulate private infrastructure operators, the first major one of which was awarded in late 1996 (strategic private investor in telecommunications). Establishment of the entity before privatization would provide comfort and certainty to investors and consumers, facilitate orderly transition of ownership, and also allow an opportunity to train regulatory personnel; (ii) the importance of establishing at least the key safeguards for the entity's independence in law, rather than decree, to reinforce the independence and stability of the new institution; and (iii) current uncertainties over the precise scope of the entity's role and responsibilities in relation to some sectors, most particularly water, telecommunications and electricity. The new law will come into effect in March 1997, prior to most key privatizations under the State's Reform Program. The scope of the law will nonetheless remain subject to resolution of uncertainities regarding the allocation of regulatory responsibilities among the federal and subnational levels. * Ensuring Sector-Specific Expertise. The main challenge in establishing multi- sectoral entities is to ensure that sector-specific expertise is not compromised. Most multi-sectoral entities have met this challenge by creating strong sector- specific departments within the entity, as well as some departments with a cross-sectoral coverage (e.g., central policy department, administration department). The formal decision-making structure for the entity remains cross-sectoral in nature and, as discussed below, typically involves professionals with cross-sectoral rather than industry-specific technical expertise. Multi-sectoral agencies may often be guided by sector-specific advisory or consultative groups that comprise representatives of users and concessionaires. These issues will be resolved through enactment of a new law creating the staffing structure of the new regulatory entity. * Ensuring Independence and Accountability. There is growing consensus internationally that the long term viability and efficiency of public services will best be achieved by moving responsibility for regulatory decisions on issues such as tariffs away from the political process and into the hands of a more independent regulatory entity. This new reform model has been adopted by a growing number of reforming countries in the Latin America and Europe. While most independent regulators are formally part of the Executive Branch of the government, the regulator has an independent legal mandate and is required to fulfill that mandate at arm's length from the day-to-day political process, the regulated industry, consumers and other interest groups. In many
 46 respects such regulators are akin to judges -- independent experts that are entrusted to make decisions in the public interest and in accordance with law. RGS new regulatory agency is part of the Executive Branch, with the governor appointing three of its seven directors. RGS chose a representative model to balance the power awarded to the governor. * Choosing the Regulators. A key issue is whether decision-making authority should be vested in an individual or a commission. To avoid undue personalization of the process and excessive concentration of power, international experience leans to creating a commission. The size should be small -- of three or perhaps five people -- to avoid slow decision-making and strengthen the accountability of individual members. A second issue is what qualifications should be required for appointment to the commission. Options are representation of particular interest groups, industry-specific experts for each regulated sector, or professionals with expertise in broad, cross-cutting disciplines. The latter appears to be the best, as it permits a broad, objective and balanced evaluation of regulatory questions from multiple perspectives. The new RGS law creates a council of seven directors appointed by the Governor (4), consumers (2) and concessionaires (1). * Views of consumers and other interest groups. To ensure adequate information for regulatory decisions, the appointed regulators can obtain the views of consumers and interest groups through special advisory or consultative bodies or by allowing these groups to present their views in regulatory proceedings. - Staffing the Entity. International experience is that "small is beautiful": a large staff increases the costs of regulation and can also encourage "excessive" regulatory interventions, such as when staff place unjustified demands for information on concessionaires primarily to justify their pay-checks. The preferred staffing strategy will usually be to start with a very small staff and engage short-term consultants to assist with specific problems encountered during the initial start-up period. Additional staff should only be recruited once the need is clearly demonstrated. A new law will create the staffing structure of RGS new regulatory entity, which is expected to be initially very small. Funding the Entity. Most independent regulatory entities are funded from levies on regulated firms or consumers, rather than the general budget. This reinforces the independence of the entity while reducing the burden on government budgets. The new law creates a conflict of interest by specifying fines as a source of revenue. This provision may be reviewed at a later stage. 2.132 The new law covers: * the general nature and mission of the entity (Articles 2-4); * the basic decision-making structure, including appointments and appeal arrangements (Articles 5-7; 10-13); * the key safeguards of independence and accountability (Articles 7-8, 14);

The Borrower would submit to the Bank the audit reports of expenditures within six months of the close of each fiscal year. The audit reports would certify that the funds were used for legitimate project activities. The procurement audit following each time-slice disbursement will cover ex-post sampling of all procurement of goods and works. The annual audit will also certify that the severance payments of the Voluntary Withdrawal Program of the state enterprises were made in accord with the applicable state law. Project Sustainability 3.48 Overall project sustainability will largely depend on the budget constraint to which the state will be subject. A federal policy prone to easily bailing out states in financial difficulties will likely undermine implementation and sustainability. Alternatively, federal policy could play an important role in encouraging the state to implement and sustain the program if it rewards good performance in lieu of bailing out bad performance. Hopefully, the Federal Government's own budget constraint will reinforce its desire to encourage reform. 3.49 In addition to outside incentives, sustainability will also depend on how easily reversible the reforms are. Clearly, privatizations and concessions will better withstand
 64 adverse changes in incentives than fiscal discipline or administrative reforms. Successful privatization of CEEE and CRT and successful concession in water, ports, and roads will improve financial performance, investment, and service delivery so as to discourage future expansion of state ownership or direct management in these sectors. On the other hand, any improvements of the state's financial situation during 1996-1998 will not protect against future episodes of financial mismanagement. Lessons Learned from Previous Operations 3.50 The Bank has extensive experience in the reform of the public sector through SALs and SECALs and with subnational development projects in Brazil, Argentina and other countries. Key lessons may be summarized as follows. First, projects must focus on a few significant reforms that are hard to reverse -- such as privatization of public enterprises and banks, and reforms passed via legislation -- and that can be fully implemented during the mandate of an elected administration. Second, project design and implementation arrangements must be flexible enough to achieve targeted reform objectives. Third, as reform projects for subnational governments can have high supervision costs, project implementation should seek to include as much private participation as possible in such areas as auditing and procurement. Finally, to ensure commitment in implementation, the government should have a strong ownership of the project components. The Bank's role should be to provide financial and technical support. Rationale for Bank Involvement 3.51 Bank involvement in RGS State Reform Program is motivated by the state's commitment to encourage development through its State Reform Program. The Federal Government has asked for the Bank's assistance in developing, implementing and financing state reforms that promote an improvement in the state's financial situation, improved public sector efficiency, and better delivery of infrastructure services. Although the Government is proceeding with its Reform Program under its own commitment, it has asked for Bank assistance both to strengthen the quality of the program as well as to finance some of its costs. The proposed project is within the Bank's current Country Assistance Strategy, which calls for support of improvements in the performance of Brazil's public sector. The Bank is considering similar projects in the states of Rio de Janeiro, Minas Gerais and Mato Grosso. Program Objective Categories 3.52 The primary objective category of the project is "Economic Management (EA)", as it seeks to improve the overall performance of RGS' public sector. Participatory Approach 3.53 The RGS Government has pursued a highly transparent and participatory approach in proposing and seeking approval of the State Reform Program. Most of the reforms in the Program have been subject to parliamnentary scrutiny. For example, legal mandates for
 65 privatization of public enterprises are being obtained for each enterprise individually. The participatory approach has gone as far as to hold public hearings for the discussion of these privatizations. In addition, ali bidding documents of concessions and privatizations have also been presented at public hearings. Project Benefits 3.54 The project will support improvements the public sector's financial performance, in economic efficiency, and in the quality of infrastructure services. It is also expected to help trigger similar reforms elsewhere in Brazil. A better financial performance of the public sector will result from an improved efficiency and reduced level of expenditures. This benefit will be achieved through measures to reduce evasion of the ICMS and through actions to control expenditures. It is a benefit because through improved financial performance RGS will be able to contain indebtedness and manage its own resources more effciently. Increased economic efficiency will also result from a reduced role of the state in infrastructure, including telecommunications, power, water, ports and roads. This means that the infrastructure sector will be able to produce more and better services for any given amount of resources as a result of privatizations and concessions. In addition, the privatizations and concessions will help mobilize much needed investment to meet supply shortfalls of infrastructure services. Finally, a project benefit will surely be its impact on a future deepening of reforms in RGS and on reforms taken by other states. Together with Rio de Janeiro and other States, RGS is a pioneering program that breaks new grounds in improved public sector management and privatization for Brazil. Project Risks 3.55 The reform programs being undertaken by a number of highly indebted Brazilian states will typically include revenue and expenditure actions to improve fiscal performance, agreements to alleviate scheduled debt service to the Federal Government, reform to reduce the burden of labor costs and a program of privatization actions. Achievement of the actions and related objectives of the reform program is subject to three key risks. First, the debt agreements, particularly in the initial years do not lower debt service to levels that are compatible with projected improvements in fiscal balance. This may impede achievement of creditworthiness. Second, lack of federal action on administrative reform will undermine efforts to reduce labor expenditure and improve fiscal balance. Third, future reversibility of actions taken by the presently committed administration may also undermine the fiscal objectives of the State Reform Programs. 3.56 The Bank's assistance strategy to Brazilian states includes state reform loans to four or five Brazilian states, in support of privatization actions and actions to improve the efficiency of expenditures. This support is coupled with investment loans in various sectors of these reforming states. Project risks are as follows. A first risk is that federal largesse in helping states weather present financial difficulties may discourage the privatizations and expenditure efficiency improvements supported by the project. This risk is somewhat contained by the Federal Government's own fiscal constraints and by the reform. A second risk is that the state's debt agreement with the Federal Government will
 66 not accomplish financial sustainability for the state. This may well happen because the parameters of the agreement will not allow a rapid decline in the debt/revenue ratio. High indebtedness and debt service may undermine the fiscal improvement objectives of the expenditure actions supported by the project. The high level of remaining indebtedness may lead to an unaffordable debt service (e.g. through high interest rates) that would generate a new debt crisis. This risk is somewhat contained by a debt agreement on a fixed 6 percent rate on the rescheduled debt. Third, CORSAN, or municipal intransigence may decrease the pace of reform in the water sector. The use of a floating time-slice disbursement will encourage the state to continue other reforms if-- for reasons beyond its control -- water reforms are delayed. Fourth, a complex reform program may test the Government's capacity to implement it. Nevertheless, thus far, the Government's team has successfully achieved passage of several complex pieces of legislation and implemented a difficult staff downsizing program. Commitment has been high, as demonstrated by firm actions to privatize telecommunications and rapid progress towards privatizing the power sector. 3.57 Finally, the state will continue to be exposed to public enterprise losses. Although the privatization program covers two important enterprises (CRT and CEEE), the state will remain exposed to risks of losses in important enterprises, including CORSAN, BANRISUL, and the Caixa Econ6mica Estadual. Only BANRISUL made a profit in 1995. Although these enterprises are reducing costs through staff reductions and branch closings (the case of BANRISUL and CEERS which may be merged), these actions could easily be reversed in the future. Losses from poor management and credit policies (including lending to public enterprises and other uncreditworthy borrowers) could be large, particularly in BANRISUL and CEERS, where total assets are Rs.$8 billion. To illustrate, a loss of only 1 percent of the joint assets of BANRISUL and CEERS alone is equivalent to about 1 percent of the state's debt, which in turn is 2 percent of the level of net revenues, a very significant amount under the state's present conditions of financial strain. There is nevertheless some comfort and an emerging track record that the present Government will be able to improve the aggregate financial performance of these enterprises during 1996-98, that some of the enterprises (CRT and CEEE) will be partially privatized during 1996-98, and that the banks are now being considered for merger and eventual privatization.

Since the beginning of 1994, the authorities have been implementing a stabilization plan that has been carefully sequenced. The first phase involved a modification of the budget to obtain a balance in the operational account of the consolidated public sector. The second phase marked the introduction of a new system of indexation of a co- temporaneous nature, intended to eliminate inertial components of inflation. The final phase, introduced in July 1994, saw the introduction of a new currency, the Real, linked to the U. S. dollar and the elimination of indexation. Stabilization policies have been based on a nominal exchange rate anchor and tight monetary policies. External payments were normalized with a debt and debt service reduction agreement with commercial banks and with arrangements under the Paris Club as a part of the stabilization plan. 2. Inflation has been reduced sharply under the plan from monthly rates of around 40 percent in mid-1994 to below 1 percent currently. The economy has grown at annual rates of about 3.5 percent in the post-stabilization period; initially, the major contribution to growth arose from a sharp rise in domestic demand associated with a reduced erosion of real incomes from inflation, rises in real wages and consumer credit expansion, but after bouts of monetary policy tightening since early 1995, domestic demand has moderated and the external contribution turned positive. 3. The fiscal adjustment seen in 1994 was sharply reversed in 1995, when an operational surplus equivalent to 1.3 percent of GDP was transformed into a deficit of 5 percent of GDP. The underlying deterioration in the fiscal balance is even greater when the strong cyclical upturn in 1995 is taken into account. The principal causes of the fiscal loosening lie in a rise in the public sector wage bill, as minimum wages and public sector pay were increased in late 1994 and early 1995, higher social security expenditures (in part related to the rise in the minimum wage), increases in outlays for interest payments on public debt, and strong increases in expenditures at states and municipalities. 4. The burden of adjustment has fallen on monetary policies. The authorities have taken periodic measures to vary reserve requirements and to impose tax and other restrictions on credit operations and capital inflows. Consequently, until very recently, real interest rates in monthly terms have ranged between 2 and 3 percent. During 1996, interest rates declined temporarily to less than 1 percent per month. The Central Bank has engaged in sterilization operations in response to foreign exchange reserve accumulation -- a development, which together with the need to fund the fiscal deficit, had led to a sharp rise in public debt to the equivalent of nearly one-third of GDP. A further cause of the rise
