 86 Annex K ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS Environmental Issues 1. Environmental problems in the State of RGS include pollution problems related to urban and industrial activities (water pollution, air pollution, solid waste), pollution problems related to agricultural activities (mainly water pollution) and degradation of the natural resource base, for example in the form of soil erosion. 2. The state can be divided into three major water basins: the Rio Guaiba Basin, the Rio Uruguai Basin and the Coastal Zone. The most severe water pollution problems affect the Rio Guaiba basin that covers 30 percent of the state's surface but includes 70 percent of the state's population, including most industrial activities and the Porto Alegre Metropolitan Area. Water pollution problems are caused by a combination of almost entirely untreated domestic wastes, industrial effluent and agriculture runoff. Water pollution reaches critical values in specific locations of the basin. Pollution damage includes health threats to, mostly lower income residents, who swim at local beaches. The Rio Uruguai drains mainly agricultural areas. Localized problems with pollution from domestic wastes and agriculture (nutrients and agro-toxics) have been detected. The Coastal Zone includes several vulnerable coastal lakes and the Lagoa dos Patos, which is the most significant estuary of southern Brazil and has significant fisheries. 3. Water quality monitoring in the Rio Guaiba Basin is undertaken at 37 monitoring points for 19 standard parameters in the Sinos (monthly), Gravatai (monthly), Cai (trimestral), and Tuquari-Antas (trimestral) sub-basins. Additional in-depth water quality studies have been conducted in several areas of industrial concentration. There are 62 monitoring points in the Coastal Zone at which water quality is assessed in two annual measuring campaigns. During the holiday months, December to February, weekly water quality analysis is carried out at the main beach locations. 4. Air quality problems include excessive particulate concentration in urban areas, caused by emissions from industry and transport and localized industrial pollution. In particular, air emissions from the Candiota coal-fired power plant in the south of the state, have led to complaints from Uruguay regarding transborder pollution from this plant. The state has 14 non-automatic monitoring stations for Total Suspended Particulates (TSP) and Sulfur Dioxide (SO2), which provide monitoring data every six days (of the 14 stations, four are located in Porto Alegre, four in Rio Grande, and one, respectively, in Montenegro, Triunfo, Estancia Velha, Bage, and Acegua). Most stations are located close to major industrial polluters. Individual measurements from July 1995 indicate that particulate concentration in parts of Porto Alegre may significantly exceed applicable standards.
 87 Environmental Policies 5. The combination of federal, state and local environmental regulations has created a complex system of requirements that covers most potentially environmentally harmful activities but is at times confusing for polluters and difficult to enforce. The objectives of environmental policy are formally defined in ambient environmental standards. The Federal Government has established water and air quality standards through resolutions of the National Environment Council (CONAMA). For example, CONAMA Resolution 20/1986 determines ambient standards for nine water use classes for the main water pollutants. In RGS, only some waterbodies (primarily in the Guaiba basin) have been classified according to water use classes. 6. At the national level, there are the PROAGUA national water quality program and the PRONAR national air quality control program, which include ambient monitoring, administration of emission licenses, and a national emissions inventory. The implementation of most policies, however, is the responsibility of the State. In RGS, the basic legal provisions for environmental management are contained in the Basic Environment Law of 1981 (Law 7,488/81), for which regulations have never been issued, and the State Constitution of 1989. A new environmental framework law is awaiting approval by the State Legislature. 7. The main instrument for pollution management is a comprehensive licensing system that was established in 1991 (Law No 9202/91) which requires a valid license for every potentially environmentally harmful activity. The firms' licensing applications contain information on technical parameters and environmental impacts based on which the state grants or refuses the license. The licensing process involves three steps: a preliminary license granted during the planning process of a new project, an installation license, and an operation license. For activities with a potentially large environmental impact, the development and evaluation of an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) forms part of the licensing process. Even though the licensing process is applicable mainly for new activities, existing companies and activities are gradually being included in the system. An environmental license determines the environmental conditions and norms under which the respective activity is permitted. 8. Current environmental management instruments are largely based on a command- and-control approach and somewhat inflexible mentality. Moreover, there is no effective link that ties environmental policies to the ambient environmental conditions in specific locations. Cross-sectoral planning and coordination of environmental policy is lacking. Economic thinking and the desire to develop flexible and cost-effective solutions to pollution problems is not yet well-developed. For example, lacking integration between effluent controls from industry and the sanitation sector undermine the development of cost-effective pollution control strategies. There has been insufficient cooperation between environmental agencies and the industry and other polluters, such as the sanitation sector, even though experience elsewhere suggests that such cooperation is critical for effective pollution reduction.

This social value does not stem from the fact that the enterprises' workers are laid-off, but rather because the redundant workers can be better used in other sectors where the demand has been identified, and from the specific efforts made to ensure that the quality of this labor force will be enhanced in the process through training. It also releases scarce public resources for better targeted and more effective uses including
 99 education, which is best completed earlier rather than through middle life literacy programs. Methodology 13. Economic costs and benefits are defined as follows: 14. The costs. The costs. of the retrenchment program in each concession are given by the sum of the net present value of: (i) the marginal productivity value of retrenched employees from the state enterprises, differentiated by year (i), employee (j), and concession area (k) (Rr ijk) (ii) the severance payments (Soj ). (iii) the early retirement payments (Pij). (iv) the training costs (T1jk). 15. Item (i) represents the services not rendered by due to employee retrenchment. Since the remaining personnel is sufficient to carry out current production levels of these enterprises, the value of the marginal production productivity of retrenched workers is assumed to be zero. 16. In an environment without budget constraints or price distortions, items (ii) and (iii) would not normally be labeled economic costs. Assuming no subsidy and no government budget constraint, these outlays would be considered income-efficient transfers to the redundant employees and would the not be included as a cost in the analysis. But Brazil does have a budget constraint and a highly distorted tax system which results in price distortions. These two terms were therefore included to recognize the importance of the opportunity costs of public funds. The underlying assumption is that the shadow price of public funds is 100 percent and that each dollar of public resources used to finance severance payments or early retirement packages has an equivalent economic cost which needs to be taken into account. This also contributes to the conservative estimates of the rate of return as the cost estimates are an upper bound of the costs rather than a lower bound. These payments are differentiated by year (i) and employee (j). 17. Item (iv), training costs, have an economic component attached as long as the training agency (or firm) has an alternative use for its resources. In this case, training will be provided by state-supported agencies that operate far below their service capacity limits. Nevertheless, the full cost of the training program was included. Training costs were estimated at Rs.$300 per employee days, and all redundant workers have been included as potential candidates. Training is differentiated by year (i) employee (), and subsystem (k).
 100 18. The pensions paid to normally retired employees are not included, since these costs would be incurred anyway. Earlier payments of regular pension have included since they are small and their impact on the internal rate of return of the project would not be significant. 19. The Benefits. The benefits of redundancy reduction in each year given by: (i) the marginal productivity value of each laid-off employee elsewhere in the economy (REjmp). (ii) the marginal productivity value of the foregone labor cost of the enterprises (LC ijk). 20. The marginal productivity value of the laid-off employee is the product of: (i) the probability of the employee's engagement in another productive activity, depends on effectiveness of the training which the employee receives, by (ii) the net income produced by such activity. RP is influenced by attributes such as age, education etc., of each employee (j), and the location (m) at which the employee is likely to find an occupation (p), "Region" (m) may or may not be the same as "Where the employee previously worked" and occupation (p) is related to the employee's attributes and the training which the employee receives. In some cases, the laid-off employee may get a job at the expense of someone else's job, and the net income contribution may be zero. But since these cases are normally rare impact on the final results would not be significant. Provision was made for these assumptions in the sensitivity analyses. 21. The marginal product of the foregone labor cost of the enterprises represents the opportunity cost of the outlays that will be saved by the retrenchment program. These savings labor costs can be used in investments in needed to provide additional service capacity, as well as further improvements in the existing system. In the economic analysis of this specific they are estimated as equivalent to the foregone labor cost. In the economic analysis of the overall project, the savings in labor costs are translated in terms of reduction in the long-run marginal cost of the services provided by these enterprises. That cost reduction is the main reason for the increased competitiveness which in turn explains the improvement of their competitiveness and market shares. Quantitative Assumptions 22. The quantitative assumptions made in estimating the return to staff reductions are conservative; in particular, it is assumed that not everyone will find a job. The probability of being rehired was computed on the basis of the time spent on the job and the average length of unemployment. Based on the information available about the employment situation in the largest metropolitan areas, the probability of finding a new job in the southern, southeastern, or center regions is 0.83. The main reason why unemployment duration is rather short is that prices adjust to clear the labor market. This implies that unemployment goes down as the price of labor declines. Those who do not find a job at their previous wage have to accept a wage cut consistent with the average probability of
 101 being employed. The reduction in wage depends on the region; wage is reduced to the average salary in the region where a worker is declared redundant. This implies wage losses of about 10 percent in the South (of which RGS is a part) and Southeast regions. Results 23. Tables M. 1 and M.2 presents the results for the two enterprises analyzed: CEEE and CRT. The net present value (NPV) of the staff retrenchment program is estimated at US$350 million for CRT and US$72 million for CEEE with a 12 percent discount rate. The internal economic rate of return (IERR) is estimated at 96 percent for the CRT and 112 percent for the CEEE. Financial Rates of Return 24. Table M. 1 and M.2 also show the financial rates of return calculated only with the costs of the program and the cost savings from retrenchment. The estimated internal rate of return was 66 percent for the CEEE and 57 percent for CRT.

 104 Annex N DESCRIPTIONS OF DISBURSEMENT COMPONENT This annex provides more detailed descriptions of each disbursement component. Information on procurement and disbursement procedures, project accounts, and auditing such be included in the PM (See Annex L). Goods, Works, Consultants and Training 1. Equipment for Reform Implementation This component will finance office equipment necessary to improve public sector efficiency, including PCs and PC software. Expenditures on this equipment, are part of the project objective of improving the efficiency of expenditures. Their economic profitability is linked to the profitability of actions to reduce the level of public expenditures and raise their effectiveness. The PM will define in detail what types of equipment would be eligible for financing and other conditions. For example, larger purchases of PCs would not be eligible without an adequate training program. Disbursement would be against the expenditures for this equipment. Accounts should facilitate the annual project audit. 2. High-Priority Investments In addition to the reforms, the project will finance high priority investment projects during the adjustment period, including: land management and rural poverty alleviation to ensure that these environmental and poverty programs are fully funded during the adjustment; and rehabilitation and maintenance of roads, schools, hospitals, and health posts to assure that the physical assets of the state do not deteriorate during the adjustment period. 3. To ensure that the investment subprojects to be financed are of the highest priority in the case of land management, rural poverty alleviation, and highway rehabilitation, financing would complement that of proposed Bank projects scheduled for Board presentation in FY97. For example, if the state complies with the SRL time-slice conditions, the SRL would finance upto US$15 million of the US$50 million of road rehabilitation works to be done in 1997 and 1998 under the proposed State Highway Management Loan to RGS. Essentially the same procedures would be applied for the proposed Land Management and Rural Poverty Alleviation Loan and the SRL would finance upto US$15 million of the US$60 million to be spent on goods, works, and consultants to be financed in 1997 and 1998. This SRLJ financing would, of course, be in addition to the financing under both loans. To avoid double counting in calculating the overall share of Bank financing for the Brazil, the SRL financing would be counted only under the loan. If these two projects are delayed, the SRL could finance subprojects in these areas using the evaluation and procurement methods similar to those which would
 105 have been used for the proposed projects. These methods would be described in the Project Manual. 4. In the case of the social sectors, simple evaluation criteria for maintenance and rehabilitation would be provided in the Project Manual. 5. Consultants The study will also finance studies needed to define or implement the reforms, training, and audits. The studies are linked to the achievement of the project objectives. They may include diagnostic or implementation studies to undertake the privatization actions in the sectors supported by the project (telecommunication, energy, roads, ports or water). There may also be studies to help implement actions that raise the efficiency and/or curtail the level of public expenditures. The economic profitability of these studies, sustainability and risks of the privatization and public expenditure actions which are discussed in the text. Severance Payments 6. The loan would finance the cost of severance pay under the voluntary downsizing effort of CRT and CEEE, and also possibly CESA, CEASA, and CORSAN. The evaluation of the component is in Annex M. Initially, the payments will be for payments in only the CRT and CEEE, but other entities and downsizing programs could be included. As these are for payments to those eligible on the PDV, Bank procurement procedures do not apply. 7. Disbursement will be against the actual expenditures payments as defined in the Annual Disbursement Plan (ADP). The project accounting system will be defined so as to make the key elements of this program auditable. The PM will describe in detail the disbursement procedures for these funds. 8. The following are the key issues that will be addressed in the PM on accounting, disbursement, and auditing for the Voluntary Departures Program: (a) The PIU will help the enterprise establish the accounting system that will produce auditable accounts. (b) The enterprise will submit estimates of the numbers of PDV participants and the amounts of total salaries and benefits net of income taxes within the amount of the approved budget. (c) The enterprise pays with its resources and sends the declaration of what has been actually paid rather than just accrued signed by the head of the operations subunit in each enterprise. (d) The operations subunit of the PIU withdraws the amount of the disbursement from the Special Account and deposits the resources in the Social Development Fund.
 106 (e) The PIU sends a request to replenish the Special Account if it has not exhausted the amount approved for the time-slice. If it has exhausted the amount, it just notes the amount in preparation for the next time-slice. (f) The PIU will make sure that the accounts established permit adequate auditing. The auditor will be private independent acceptable to the Bank. The private audit will cover only eligible expenditures. The auditor will be contracted early and will do a test preaudit to make sure that the accounts are fully auditable. The audits will be done in a timely manner. The second and third time-slices will be released only after the approval of the audit report for the project expenses for the previous fiscal year. The audit of severance payments will include the analysis of an adequate sample of payments to assure that the principles of the staff reductions are being enforce where pertinent to assure that all of the rules are being enforced. Grants 9. These include transfers to municipalities and private institutions. They cover incremental expenditures for early childhood, public health, sanitation and basic education. These expenditures are justified on the grounds of alleviating the social impact that the reform program may have, particularly arising from the financial duress that the public sector will experience in its quest for fiscal balance. Incremental Recurrent Costs 10. These are defined as direct (i.e., non-transfer) costs incurred by the RGS government in connection with social assistance programs also aimed at mitigating the social impact of reforms. These target direct additional expenditures for public health, education and training. They are justified on the same grounds as the grants discussed above. 11. An example of these costs is the decentralization of school materials purchasing and contracting of small repairs to democratically elected school councils and directors in each school. The SRL will finance incremental recurrent costs of the program. In 1996, a law was passed which made each school a relatively autonomous public entity to be administered by a democratically elected director and school council. The state began to transfer the responsibility for purchase of supplies (e.g., pencils, paper, chalk, etc.) and also for minor repairs (e.g., repair of broken windows and painting) to special funds administered by these decentralized school units. The state feels that these associations are open to closer scrutiny by the local community and should, therefore, be more accountable. 12. To participate in the school support decentralization reform, a school board must meet the requirements established in the legislation, including adequate capacity to control the use of funds. At the present time, about 2,100 of the 3,000 schools have formed
 107 school boards and 900 of these have be certified by the SEE as having met the requirements for receiving the funds. Most of the uncertified school units are expected to qualify by the end of this year. 13. The certified boards will enter into annual contracts with the SEE to transfer funds. The amount of the transfer to each school is determined using indices based on the size of the school and its location. Using these indices, the amounts transferred annually to the school boards would range from US$250 to US$151,000. The contract states that with SEE which will permit the transfer of State funds that the associations can use exclusively to purchase school supplies and materials, and small repairs. 14. Disbursement would be against the amount actually transferred to certified school boards by the state. The budget line should contain only transfers going to certified school boards. The amounts to be submitted for disbursement should be included in the Annual Disbursement Plan (ADP).
 108 Annex 0 LESSONS LEARNED FROM PREVIOUS BANK EXPERIENCE IN THE SECTOR 1. The State Reform Loan for RGS draws on lessons of experience from a number of Bank projects of similar scope and design in both the Latin America region and Brazil. As the Bank and other institutions are increasingly supporting regional development, a wider range of experiences in operationalizing and implementing these projects can be utilized. In addition, the Bank's experience with subnational government projects has evolved rapidly since the adoption of these fiscal and political reforms in the 1988 Constitution, offering many country-specific insights. Subnational Development Project 2. Complex project design has often been cited as a key reason for weakening importunate components of subnational development projects. Aspects such as institutional development and financial management are often neglected in these projects, due to the high demand placed on state implementation and coordination capacities. 3. Experience shows that by identifying and designing certain aspects of the project early in the project preparation process allows for greater flexibility and improved project implementation. In the case of the Minas Gerais Municipal Management and Environmental Infrastructure Project (Ln. 3639-BR), many of the Terms of Reference to be used and implementation arrangements were discussed during the project's preparation phase. This helped shape the dialogue between the Bank and the state, and, moreover clarified and better defined project objectives and scope for both parties. Increased borrower involvement during these stages also has the benefit of giving governments greater project "ownership," which often leads to improved project implementation. 4. In its 1992 review of urban and municipal projects in Brazil, OED found that many projects did not pay enough attention to the external environment in which they would be implemented. Tailoring project implementation periods to political mandates is particularly importunate in the case of Brazil, as it helps to capture government support for a project. As an alternative, projects that have a flexible project design can easily accommodate shifting political priorities. Additionally, any pilot programs needed to be quickly implemented to capitalize on a climate of favorable political and community support. 5. The Brazilian Northeast Rural Development Program (NRDP) projects found that incorporating aspects of public involvement in the project can lead to greater ownership and cooperation by the public. Public involvement can diffuse otherwise difficult political situations, and in the case of the NRDP can lead to greater local government
 109 accountability. In addition, the government can lower future (political) costs of trying to overcome opposition during implementation once the project has been agreed upon by including the public in the decision-making process. Public participation can also help identify places where conflict can either slow or derail project components. Project Sector Reforms in Brazil 6. The Bank's experience in Brazil demonstrates the need to work within existing institutions -- regardless of how weak -- to minimize lags in project implementation. Technical assistance has been the most common tool used to bolster municipal governments. Training can also help created better skilled staff. 7. One of the more relevant projects with respect to design and scope of the SRL- RGS is the Brazil Public Sector Management Loan (PSML -- Ln. 2721-BR). The PSML sought to develop planning and management capacity on the federal level in the areas of sector and project analysis, multi-year investment planning, and program monitoring. Another major component of the project was an integrated budget information and control system. Relevant lessons of experience include: - Project design should not be overly ambitious since the loan size, the project's operational complexity, and number of project component can ultimately burden both the Borrower and the Bank during implementation and supervision. - The project can benefit from firm budget commitments from the government and clear design links if certain aspects of the project, such as Terms of Reference, are agreed to prior to loan signing. - The overly flexible use of funds by the Borrower often leads to management problems, Moreover, too many unallocated funds can pressure the government to finance otherwise low-priority activities. - Training activities will help increase the technical capacity of the public service, but do not necessarily lead to any corresponding increase in wage compensation. - In the case of Brazil, the Borrower should seek ways to hire consultants and purchase necessary goods within local procurement legislation in terms satisfactory to the Bank. 8. Civil service staff training alone cannot create a more efficient civil service. This is particularly true in the PSML due to Brazil's inadequate wage policy for public sector employees. Civil servants earn comparatively much less than their private sector counterparts, and their wages have eroded over time in real terms due to economic and fiscal difficulties. Moreover, in the quest for decentralization and downsizing, a high number of qualified and skilled staff often leave public service for voluntary reasons, or
 110 due to poorly targeted reduction strategies (such as across-the-boards cuts or wage compression). 9. In order to remedy these problems, larger problems within the civil service need to be addressed. Solutions can include redefining of the role and functions of the government and the improving the quality of delivery of government services in light of optimal government size, needed skills and improved service delivery. Well-planned and targeted reduction or reassignments of staff can also maximize efficiency. Privatization of Public Enterprises in Argentina 10. Under the Public Enterprise Reform Project (Ln. 3291 -AR) in Argentina, the following lessons were learned. The initiative to privatize was entirely the Government's. The Bank was vital in providing financial and technical support, but never set the basic policy objective. 11. The Bank prudently kept a low profile; in spite of an ubiquitous Bank presence, privatization never became a "World Bank Program" in the eyes of political or public opinion. 12. A large amount of relevant sector work had been done by the Bank before there was any indication that a privatization program might be possible. Since at the time, the chances for any lending resulting from this work were quite low, it may well be thought of as a high risk gamble. It paid off, however, without this technical work it would have been difficult for the new Government to seize the moment and push ahead with privatization at the point where a pervasive sense of national crisis gave it the needed political support. 13. Implementation was greatly enhanced by a highly effective Project Unit. The fact that the head of the Unit participated, from the beginning, in Loan discussions and formal negotiations, enabled the Unit to play a constructive role during implementation, since he was fully aware of the backgrounds and rationales of the often complex issues and of the actions required from the many agencies involved. 14. The Bank's investments in Loan Formation and Administration was heavy (about 612 staff weeks) but vital. Without it, the program might have come to a stop at critical junctures. 15. The Bank's imaginative use of adjustment lending, in allowing visible application of counterpart proceeds to finance severance payments, was decisive in making railroad privatization feasible. But its justification hinged on two circumstances: monitoring to prevent rehiring or replacement and, even more important, imminent privatization, after which the pressures to overstaff would, presumably, largely disappear.
 111 Operational Aspects 16. Disbursement was an historic problem in Brazil due to the long-standing incompatibility between Brazil's federal procurement law and Bank guidelines. Disbursement lags also persisted due to federal regulation that mandated all Special Account be held in the Central Bank in Brasilia. In 1993, federal legislation was enacted to allow public entities to hold projects accounts in institutions outside the Central Bank. Concrete steps have also been taken to bring procurement in line with Bank standards thorough the issuing of Standard Bidding Documents that were agreed upon by the Federal Government and the Bank. 17. Project financing should use a simple, transparent flow of funds to minimize bureaucratic delays. Agreements on key disbursement and procurement mechanisms should be made as early as possible, and transparent as possible. By adopting standardized procurement documents, as well as spelling out key aspects of and all other procedures. Another means is to raise the thresholds for all ex-ante reviews as high as feasible. 18. OED's recommendations for improving the monitoring of urban development projects include: - a system to monitor implementation adequately should be put in place prior to project start-up to strengthen project management and facilitate subsequent evaluation; - use clearly defined and measurable indicator to permit the monitoring of progress toward the achievement of these goals in operations which contains substantial institutional development objectives; and - operations that contain substantial institutional development objects should include clearly defined and measurable indicator to permit monitoring progress so as to achieve these goals. 19. In order to improve overall project execution, the Bank has decentralized many of its supervision responsibilities to the field. The experience provided by the Argentine Provincial Development Project (Loan 3280-AR) has shown the need to contract out certain basic management tasks (such as review of documents, audits, and monitoring) given the large burden that "portfolio" and multi-sector projects place on project and Bank staff. For several decades, this has been as established practice with Chile's Ministry of Public Works. The Ministry contracts a firm for a designated period, and it renews contracts with the same firm to ensure continuity. Consultants report to the Ministry and supervise all works under the Ministry's jurisdiction; they prepare quarterly reports, participate actively in discussions during supervision missions, and draft aide-memoires. Supervision by the Ministry can be supplemented by annual on-site inspection by Bank staff. This practice has contributed significantly to the reduction of Bank staff supervision.

doc.repnme: Brazil - Rio Grande do Sul State Reform Loan Project
doc.abstracts: The diagnosis and framework for much of the fiscal adjustment of the reform program for the Rio Grande do Sul (RGS) State Reform Loan Project was developed in a prior sector study that presented options to address the state's debt crises. The objective of the State Reform Project is to improve efficiency in the government's service delivery through privatization and to improve the state's fiscal condition. The project is tailored to support successful implementation of RGS's more limited privatization and fiscal reforms. Its components comprise technical assistance, restructuring of public enterprises that adopt voluntary departure programs, and subprojects and programs to mitigate the reform program's costs, including priority investments and social assistance projects. Selected reforms include actions to privatize the Rio Grande do Sul telecommunications company and the state power company, and to award concessions of water and sewage services, port services, and road maintenance. The environmental targets set for the new utilities will be a critical factor determining both the economic feasibility and the environmental consequences of restructuring; thus, a consistent set of targets and obligations for the restructured utilities will have to be developed early in the process. Other components include reform-related studies, audits, and training; reform-related equipment and rehabilitation works; high priority investments in land management and rural poverty alleviation; highway, school, and hospital rehabilitation; severance pay to employees of reforming state enterprises; and transfers and non-transfers to municipalities and private institutions (to cushion the reform's impact) for incremental, recurrent expenditures in early childhood, public health, sanitation, and basic education.
